verb.description: Watch over in order to protect or control.
examples: the gates were guarded by uniformed soldiers
they were sent to guard villagers from attack by bandits
the company fiercely guarded its independence

noun.description: A person who keeps watch, especially a soldier or other person formally assigned to protect a person or to control access to a place.
examples: he distracted the soldier on guard duty

noun.description: A device worn or fitted to prevent injury or damage.
A defensive posture adopted in a boxing, fencing, or martial arts contest or in a fight.
examples: this kick can curl around an otherwise effective guard

noun.description: An official who rides on and is in general charge of a train.
Each of two offensive players positioned either side of the center.

phrases: Officers did not reveal whether any travel documents were found at the flat, where armed police today stood guard.
All day, U.S. choppers circled overhead, while on the ground, Iraqi police and soldiers stood guard.
Police officers stood guard at either end of the churchyard on the morning after the assault and fielded questions from visitors to the church.
Before the trial began, police armed with submachine guns and shotguns stood guard as vans brought the handcuffed defendants to the courthouse.
Floral tributes, many of them white roses and daffodils, were placed around a white flag of St George brought by a mourner, with a lone policeman standing guard.
origin: Late Middle English (in the sense care, custody): from Old French garde (noun), garder (verb), of West Germanic origin. Compare with ward.
